awd_titl_txt: Justice-Centered Climate Change Pedagogy Through Placed-Based, Student-Driven Action Projects
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

In US classrooms, climate change teaching is primarily focused on scientific, rather than social or political, understandings of the causes and consequences of climate change or environmental justice. However, worldwide, students from Black, Indigenous, and other Communities of Color bear a disproportionate brunt of environmental burdens and poorer health outcomes resulting from those burdens compared to their peers. Justice-centered climate pedagogy, inspired by Morales-Doyle’s (2017) concept of “justice-centered science pedagogy,” serves as an opportunity for students to become “transformative intellectuals,” learning about both the science and social context surrounding the climate change issues impacting their communities. However, there are significant barriers to implementing justice-centered climate pedagogy in terms of teacher preparedness, lack of curriculum, and misalignment between the Next Generation Science Standards and justice-centered pedagogy.  This project is designed to examine professional development strategies for supporting teachers in implementing justice-centered climate pedagogy.

The Oakland Teachers Advancing Climate Action (OTACA) Program is a program through which Oakland Unified School District teachers are supported in implementing justice-centered, student-led projects focused on local climate and environmental justice phenomena. Beyond justice-centered climate change pedagogy, OTACA is centered on the idea that teachers are learners that who can grow in their craft and experience shifts in epistemologies and understandings in much the same way that students do. This study is designed to collaboratively learn with and support the OTACA planning committee via design-based research to address the following research themes. First is to investigate how different project activities (data collection, storytelling, engaging data through critical lenses, and taking action) impact students’ epistemologies of knowledge and action. Second is to observe trajectories of teacher understandings and practice relating to justice-centered climate change pedagogy. Questions in this theme include: How wide is the gap between teacher intentions and practice, what contributes to that gap, and what supports can be used to narrow that gap? The third theme of this overall research effort asks: How do various actors within school districts work to promote justice-centered climate change learning? 

The project responds to the STEM Education Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (STEM Ed PRF) program that aims to enhance the research knowledge, skills, and practices of recent doctorates in STEM, STEM education, education, and related disciplines to advance their preparation to engage in fundamental and applied research that advances knowledge within the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In US classrooms, climate change is not consistently taught, and often introduced as unsettled science. Furthermore, instruction is most often focused on scientific, rather than social or political, understandings of the causes and consequences of climate change. When action is the target of climate change pedagogy, targeted actions are typically individual rather than collective, and not centered on environmental justice. This is problematic, because climate change is both a legacy and a multiplier of environmental racism and structural inequalities. Casting climate change education as a science topic and climate action as an individual problem are also both problematic because of the high rate of youth (around 75%) reporting that climate change has a deleterious impact on their own mental health. Because of the social causes and consequences of climate change paired with mental health burden that it puts on students, the climate change education that students need is centered in social justice.

Through this postdoctoral research fellowship, PI-Fitzmaurice explored what justice-centered climate change education (modeled after Morales-Doyles’ (2017) conception of justice-centered science pedagogy) could look like in three contexts: individual classrooms, a professional development program focused on local issues of climate justice, serving ~35 teachers, and community organizing at the school district level.

Intellectual Merrit

Fitzmaurice found that at the classroom level, engaging students with local, environmental justice projects made students feel more connected to their own communities and increased students’ local knowledge. Students interviewed as part of this project expressed an increased sense that they could make change in their own communities.

Reporting on the professional development program with which she worked through this fellowship, Fitzmaurice shared a vision of justice-centered climate change pedagogy and a template for supporting teachers in growing towards that framework together (Fitzmaurice & Barton, 2024) in community with one another, their students, and their broader communities. Through teacher interviews and classroom observations, however, Fitzmaurice found that many of the teachers she worked with struggled to center justice throughout the action projects with which they engaged their students. For example, in Fitzmaurice & Wilkerson (2024), she defined orientations of action as either activist (reimagining systems of oppression such as racism, colonialism, etc) or bureaucratic (leveraging systems of oppression). Tracing classroom project trajectories through time, she found that while most projects were framed with an activist orientation, projects trended towards bureaucracy over time. This finding highlights an area of focus for future scholars studying student climate action projects and presents an opportunity for the creation professional development interventions.

Fitzmaurice also investigated community organizing for climate change education across four school districts through a multiple-case study approach, using interviews, school district documents and recordings, and local media reports as data (Fitzmaurice and Wilkerson, 2024b; Fitzmaurice, in preparation). Through this study, she found a broad set of stakeholders engaged in organizing in support of resources and district support for climate change education and that across all districts and stakeholders, students, curriculum coordinators, and retired teachers were central to organizing efforts. Although all stakeholders interviewed expressed support for students learning about climate change through “taking action” there were substantial differences in values expressed by stakeholders across districts. These differences were often stratified by districts’ racial and socio-economic demographics. For example, stakeholders from the two wealthier districts, with a lower percentage of African American and Latino students emphasized student action in the form of community service in support of sustainability, while stakeholders from the other two districts activism and fighting environmental racism. The values differences observed through interviews translated into district documents. While the study did not investigate the extent to which these values translated into classroom instruction, the study poses the question of how these difference in values across school districts in which there is support for climate change instruction might lead to differences in climate change instruction even in places where there is broad support for teaching climate change in schools.

Broader Impacts

Through the professional development program this grant supported, PI – Fitzmaurice supported more than 35 teachers in bringing climate change and environmental justice projects into their classrooms as they supported their more than 2700 students. In addition to professional development sessions on mapping, street trees, and youth activism, support included activities such as instructional support as a guest air quality scientist, technical support for teachers using online mapping tools, and connections to community organizations. Student projects were diverse in nature and ranged from elementary students documenting the urban heat island effect on their playground and working to a few shade trees on their campus to high school students organizing turnout for community meetings regarding local air quality.

Beyond the OTACA program, this grant supported workshops at the California Science Educators conference, and presentations at the American Geophysical Union, the National Association for Researcher in Science Teaching Conference, and the International Society for Learning Sciences conference.
